contents.title: Documentation
contents.description: Telegraph is a Laravel package that enables easy Telegram Bots interaction

children.value: Telegraph is a Laravel package for fluently interacting with Telegram Bots made by
Get the full source code at

props.code:
return [
    /*
     * Telegram api base url, it can be overridden
     * for self-hosted servers
     */
    'telegram_api_url' => 'https://api.telegram.org/',

    /*
     * Sets Telegraph messages default parse mode
     * allowed values: html|markdown|MarkdownV2
     */
    'default_parse_mode' => Telegraph::PARSE_HTML,

    /*
     * Sets the handler to be used when Telegraph
     * receives a new webhook call.
     *
     * For reference, see https://defstudio.github.io/telegraph/webhooks/overview
     */
    'webhook_handler' => DefStudio\Telegraph\Handlers\EmptyWebhookHandler::class,

    /*
     * Sets a custom domain when registering a webhook. This will allow a loca telegram bot api server
     * to reach the webhook. Disabled by default
     *
     * For reference, see https://core.telegram.org/bots/api#using-a-local-bot-api-server
     */
    // 'custom_webhook_domain' => 'http://my.custom.domain';

    /*
     * If enabled, Telegraph dumps received
     * webhook messages to logs
     */
    'debug_mode' => false,

    /*
     * If enabled, unknown webhook commands are
     * reported as exception in application logs
     */
    'report_unknown_webhook_commands' => true,

    'security' => [
        /*
         * if enabled, allows callback queries from unregistered chats
         */
        'allow_callback_queries_from_unknown_chats' => false,

        /*
         * if enabled, allows messages and commands from unregistered chats
         */
        'allow_messages_from_unknown_chats' => false,

        /*
         * if enabled, store unknown chats as new TelegraphChat models
         */
        'store_unknown_chats_in_db' => false,
    ],

    /*
     * Set model class for both TelegraphBot and TelegraphChat,
     * to allow more customization.
     *
     * Bot model must be or extend `DefStudio\Telegraph\Models\TelegraphBot::class`
     * Chat model must be or extend `DefStudio\Telegraph\Models\TelegraphChat::class`
     */
    'models' => [
        'bot' => DefStudio\Telegraph\Models\TelegraphBot::class,
        'chat' => DefStudio\Telegraph\Models\TelegraphChat::class,
    ],

    'storage' => [
        /**
         * Default storage driver to be used for Telegraph data
         */
        'default' => 'file',

        'stores' => [
            'file' => [
                /**
                 * Telegraph cache driver to be used, must implement
                 * DefStudio\Telegraph\Contracts\StorageDriver contract
                 */
                'driver' => \DefStudio\Telegraph\Storage\FileStorageDriver::class,

                /*
                 * Laravel Storage disk to use. See /config/filesystems/disks for available disks
                 * If 'null', Laravel default store will be used,
                 */
                'disk' => 'local',

                /**
                 * Folder inside filesystem to be used as root for Telegraph storage
                 */
                'root' => 'telegraph',
            ],
            'cache' => [
                /**
                 * Telegraph cache driver to be used, must implement
                 * DefStudio\Telegraph\Contracts\StorageDriver contract
                 */
                'driver' => \DefStudio\Telegraph\Storage\CacheStorageDriver::class,

                /*
                 * Laravel Cache store to use. See /config/cache/stores for available stores
                 * If 'null', Laravel default store will be used,
                 */
                'store' => null,

                /*
                 * Prefix to be prepended to cache keys
                 */
                'key_prefix' => 'tgph',
            ],
        ],
    ],
];

contents.title: Messages
contents.description: Messages can be sent to a Telegram chat using a TelegraphChat model

children.value: Messages can be sent to a Telegram chat using a
// this will use the default parsing method set in config/telegraph.php
Telegraph allows sending complex messages by setting some options:
Updates an existing message instead of sending a new one
The message can be sent as a reply by setting the original message ID
Forces the user to reply to the message. For more information see
Use this method to forward messages of any kind.

Use this method to copy messages of any kind.
The method is analogous to the method forwardMessage, but the copied message doesn't have a link to the original message.
Protects message contents from forwarding and saving
. Users will receive a notification with no sound.
Disables link previews for links in this message
Telegraph method allows to remove a message from a chat/group/channel
A message can be deleted if it was sent less than 48h ago and if it
by the bot or if the bot

contents.title: Message Keyboards
contents.description: A keyboard can be added to a message in order to offer a set of options to the user:

children.value: A keyboard can be added to a message in order to offer a set of options to the user:
A keyboard can be added to a message using the
has a fluent way to define its buttons and other properties (rows, button chunking, etc.):
buttons can be set up using the
method and are defined as a
Additionally, a keyboard can be added to a message using a closure:
can be defined using its fluent methods and can be of three types:
to be handled by a custom webhook
and are used to open an external url when pressed:
and are used to start a telegram bot
and are used to start a telegram widget

Pressing the button will prompt the user to select one of their chats,
open that chat and insert the bot's username and the specified inline query
in the input field. The query text may be empty, in which case just the
bot's username will be inserted. (see

Additionally, an inline query button may act for the current chat
(so, would skip the destination chat prompt) only if
A keyboard will normally place one button per row, this behaviour can be customized by defining rows, by setting individual buttons width or by chunking buttons
A button relative width can be set using a float number the total width percentage to be taken. Buttons will flow through the rows according to their width
this example would define two buttons on the first row and a large button on the second one:
A button default width is 1 (that's to say, the entire row width)
Each width is defined as a float between 0 and 1 that represents the floating point percentage of the row taken by the button.
each button will fill the current row or flow in the subsequent one if there isn't enough space left
Buttons can be authomatically chunked in rows using the
This example would return a first row of two buttons, a second row of two buttons and the last row with the remaining button.
A message keyboard can be replaced by a new one by submitting its
A keyboard can be removed from a message by submitting its
method allows to execute a closure when the given condition is verified
method allows to change buttons layout from left-to-right to right-to-left (RTL).

contents.title: Reply Keyboards
contents.description: When sending a message, Telegram can be instructed to replace the standard phone keyboard with a custom one (see here for detailed info):

children.value: When sending a message, Telegram can be instructed to replace the standard phone keyboard with a custom one (see
A keyboard can be added to a message using the
has a fluent way to define its buttons and other properties (rows, button chunking, etc.):
buttons can be set up using the
method and are defined as a
Additionally, a keyboard can be added to a message using a closure:
A keyboard will normally place one button per row, this behaviour can be customized by defining rows, by setting individual buttons width or by chunking buttons
A button relative width can be set using a float number the total width percentage to be taken. Buttons will flow through the rows according to their width
this example would define two buttons on the first row and a large button on the second one:
A button default width is 1 (that's to say, the entire row width)
Each width is defined as a float between 0 and 1 that represents the floating point percentage of the row taken by the button.
each button will fill the current row or flow in the subsequent one if there isn't enough space left
Buttons can be authomatically chunked in rows using the
This example would return a first row of two buttons, a second row of two buttons and the last row with the remaining button.

Clients can be requested to resize the keyboard vertically for optimal fit (e.g., make the keyboard smaller if there are just two rows of buttons). Defaults to false, in which case the custom keyboard is always of the same height as the app's standard keyboard.

Requests clients to hide the keyboard as soon as it's been used. The keyboard will still be available, but clients will automatically display the usual letter-keyboard in the chat  the user can press a special button in the input field to see the custom keyboard again
Adding a placeholder for the input field
The placeholder to be shown in the input field when the keyboard is active can be set with:
Applying a keyboard to a specific user

A keyboard can be applied to specific users only. Targets: 1) users that are @mentioned in the text of the Message object; 2) if the bot's message is a reply (has reply_to_message_id), sender of the original message.
Example: A user requests to change the bot's language, bot replies to the request with a keyboard to select the new language. Other users in the group don't see the keyboard.
A reply keyboard can be removed from clients with this call:
Removing a keyboard for a specific user
To remove the keyboard for a specific user, simply pass
Targets: 1) users that are @mentioned in the text of the Message object; 2) if the bot's message is a reply (has reply_to_message_id), sender of the original message.

Example: A user votes in a poll, bot returns confirmation message in reply to the vote and removes the keyboard for that user, while still showing the keyboard with poll options to users who haven't voted yet.
method allows to execute a closure when the given condition is verified

contents.title: Attachments
contents.description: Telegraph supports different types of attachments both from local files, remote urls and existing files on Telegram servers (using their file_id)

children.value: Telegraph supports different types of attachments both from local files, remote urls and existing files on Telegram servers (using their file_id)
Attachments methods only supports required parameters, optional parameters can be sent through Telegraph
Photos can be sent through Telegraph
Sent Photos can be edited with the
Animations can be sent through Telegraph
Sent Animations can be edited with the
Videos can be sent through Telegraph
Sent Videos can be edited with the
Audio (.MP3 or .M4A format) can be sent through Telegraph
Sent Audio messages can be edited with the
Vocals can be sent through Telegraph
Documents can be sent through Telegraph
Sent Documents can be edited with the
A location attachment can be sent through Telegraph
A contact attachment can be sent through Telegraph
An animated emoji attachment that will display a random value can be sent through Telegraph
Different items can be used as "dice"
When sending files, some options are available:
Sent attachment captions can be edited with the

contents.title: Webhooks Overview
contents.description: Telegram bots can interact with chats and users through a webhook system that enables it to be updated about chats changes, new commands and user interactions without continuously polling Telegram APIs for updates.

children.value: Telegram bots can interact with chats and users through a webhook system that enables it to be updated about chats changes, new commands and user interactions without continuously polling Telegram APIs for updates.
By default webhooks can handle incoming requests from "known" chats (the one stored in database as TelegraphChat models) and will reject all others. In order to handle unknown chats see
A default "do nothing" handler is shipped with Telegraph installation, it can only handle a single chat command:
And answers with the ID of the chat the command is issued into. It is useful to get the ChatID in order to register a new chat in Telegraph
In order to write custom webhook and commands handlers the default handler must be switched with a custom one
A custom webhook handler must extend
and has to be registered in
A detailed description of how WebhookHandlers work can be found in the next sections
By default webhooks can handle incoming requests from "known" chats (the one stored in database as TelegraphChat models) and will reject all others.
Callback queries, commands and messages handling from unknown chats can be enabled from telegraph config in security settings:

props.code:
'security' => [
    /*
     * if enabled, allows callback queries from unregistered chats
     */
    'allow_callback_queries_from_unknown_chats' => true,

    /*
     * if enabled, allows messages and commands from unregistered chats
     */
    'allow_messages_from_unknown_chats' => true,

     /*
     * if enabled, store unknown chats as new TelegraphChat models
     */
    'store_unknown_chats_in_db' => true,
],

children.value: * if enabled, allows callback queries from unregistered chats
* if enabled, allows messages and commands from unregistered chats
* if enabled, store unknown chats as new TelegraphChat models

if you are implementing a custom bot management logic, you can unregister a webhook using the

or using a parameter inside the method call:

contents.title: Webhook Request Types
contents.description: Telegraph can handle four incoming webhook request types: Chat Messages,  Chat Commands, Callback Queries and Inline Queries:

children.value: Telegraph can handle four incoming webhook request types:
Plain chat messages (messages that are not commands or queries) can be handled by overriding
// in this example, a received message is sent back to the chat
A bot can read non-command/queries messages only if its
is disabled. To change a bot privacy settings see
You can also handle any content of Telegram, like: Contact, Photo, Voice and etc...
// checks that the contact matches the sender ID
Telegraph bots can receive commands from chats where they are registered. A command is a telegram message has a
) char followed by a descriptive word:
what the command will trigger is up to the developer, but a webhook will react to it if it has a public method named as the command:
optionally, the handler method can receive the command parameters:
The full chat message data can be retrieved through the

The default Telegraph's behaviour for unknown commands is to report an exception in application log (this can be disabled in telegraph config) and
answer the user that the command is unknown
A custom handler can be defined by overriding the
Bots messages may ship with keyboard of buttons that trigger actions when pressed:
when pressed, a new call will be forwarded to the webhook with the following payload
action will be handled by a corresponding public method in the custom webhook handler:
The full callback query data can be retrieved through the

contents.title: Manual updates polling
contents.description: As an aternative to set up a webhook, a bot updates can be fetched by periodically polling Telegram APIs

children.value: As an aternative to set up a webhook, a bot updates can be fetched by periodically polling Telegram APIs
Manual updates polling is not available if a webhook is set up for the bot. Webhook should be remove first using its
in order to get the updates, an
the call will result in a collection of
instances, one for each update, sorted by the oldest one.
It is advised to keep track of the
in order to avoid processing the same update multiple times.
The content of each update depends on the update type (
) and on the specific message type. Refer to the

contents.title: Incoming Data
contents.description: Data obtained from manual polling or webhooks is available through a set of DTO:

children.value: Data obtained from manual polling or webhooks is available through a set of DTO:
contains incoming data (a message or a callback query)
holding the message last edit date
a boolean flag that states the message is protected from forwarding and download
holding data about the message's sender
holding data about a forwarded message's original sender
holding data about the chat to which the message belongs to
that the current message is replying
holding data about the contained image resolutions
holding data about the contained animation
holding data about the contained audio
holding data about the contained document
holding data about the contained video
holding data about the contained location
holding data about the contained contact data
holding data about the contained voical message
holding the list of users that joined the group/supergroup
holding data about the user that left the group/supergroup

that holds the key/value pairs of the callback query data

type of the chat, from which the inline query was sent. Can be either sender for a private chat with the inline query sender, private, group, supergroup, or channel. The chat type should be always known for requests sent from official clients and most third-party clients, unless the request was sent from a secret chat

contents.title: Telegraph Entities Storage
contents.description: Telegraph offers a quick, multi driver, data storage solution to save and retrieve information about Bots, Chats and Users. A fine grained configuration is available in the storage section of Telegraph configuration file

children.value: offers a quick, multi driver, data storage solution to save and retrieve information about Bots, Chats and Users. A fine grained configuration is available in the
Telegraph implements, by default, contextual storage for Bots, Chats and User DTOs. Additionally a storage can be added to every class, it is only needed to implement the
data storage is available through its
data storage is available through its
data storage is available through its
Depending on the application needs, multiple drivers can be
A default storage driver can be set in
config and it will be used when
A file storage driver saves data in json files inside the disk/folder defined in Telegraph
with the above configuration this code will store the
A cache storage driver saves data using Laravel Cache system following Telegraph
with the above configuration this code will store the
Telegraph can store model references as well: when a model is found inside data stored, it is internally converted in a class/id pair and the model is retrieved from DB when the value is fetched:

contents.title: Fake Telegram interaction
contents.description: In order to avoid sending real messages to Telegram when testing, the Telegraph facade offers a ::fake() method to start registering sent messages internally instead of sending them to Telegram APIs.

children.value: In order to avoid sending real messages to Telegram when testing, the
method to start registering sent messages internally instead of sending them to Telegram APIs.
// the message won be actually sent to telegram, but can still be asserted
If needed for testing purpose, the
helper can accept an array of responses to be returned for each endpoint call:
//$response will be a Response containing a json body: {"result":"oooook"}
For debugging purpose, a dump of the sent data can be obtained with:

contents.title: Fake messages assertions
contents.description: The ::fake() facade helper enables a number of assertions for checking its activity

children.value: facade helper enables a number of assertions for checking its activity
asserts that a message was sent to Telegram with the given text
//will check that the sent text is exactly 'hello'
//will check that the sent text contains 'hello'
asserts that no messages where sent to Telegram
asserts that the given data was sent to a Telegram API endpoint
asserts that the given files were sent to a Telegram API endpoint
asserts that the given data was sent to a Telegram API endpoint
asserts that the given incoming file was stored
asserts that a webhook register request has been sent
asserts that a webhook debug info request has been sent
asserts that a webhook reply has been sent with the given text
